commander.name: Major-General Walter Clutterbuck
commander.previous_service: Took command in 1941, led division from UK to North Africa. Remained in command through Tunisia and Italy campaigns until 1943.

tanks.note: Infantry division - no organic tanks. Supported by 142nd Regiment Royal Armoured Corps (Churchill tanks) during operations.

anti_aircraft.note: AA protection provided by attached units from First Army AA resources

supply_logistics.supply_status: ADEQUATE - Division arrived fresh from UK on 9 March 1943 with full equipment and supplies. Supply lines from Algiers and Bone ports (350-400km). Part of First Army's buildup for final offensive (May 1943). Limited Q1 combat activity (division arrived late March).
notes: Division arrived 9 March 1943 - only 3 weeks of Q1 1943 in theater
Moved to Medjez-Bou Arada area for acclimatization and preparation
Full British First Army logistical support from Algiers
No major combat in Q1 - division preparing for May offensive
Q1 focus: training, acclimatization, reconnaissance of sector

weather_environment.season_quarter: Q1 1943 (March only for this division) - Late Winter/Early Spring, Northern Tunisia
weather_environment.terrain_type: Medjez-Bou Arada sector - hilly terrain with river valleys, more fertile than Western Desert. Mixed agricultural land and rocky hills. Better cover than desert but more restrictive for armor.
notes: Northern Tunisia significantly different from Western Desert
More rainfall and vegetation
Hilly terrain channels movement into valleys
March: transition from winter mud to spring conditions
Division arrived from UK - adjustment to Mediterranean climate needed

subordinate_units.note: Participated in April-May 1943 offensive operations with 142nd RAC tank support
Defended 'Banana Ridge' near Medjez el Bab on 21 April 1943
Guards brigade replaced 25th Tank Brigade before Tunisia deployment. Later replaced by 18th Infantry Brigade from 1st Armoured Division.

tactical_doctrine.role: British First Army infantry division for final Tunisia offensive. Division arrived 9 March 1943, spent Q1 in acclimatization, training, and reconnaissance. Prepared for Operation Vulcan (final offensive, 6-13 May 1943). Supported by 142nd Regiment Royal Armoured Corps (Churchill infantry tanks) for breakthrough operations.
special_capabilities: Fresh division from UK with full training and equipment
Guards brigade provides elite infantry component
Full complement of new 17-pounder AT guns
Trained for combined arms operations with Churchill tank support
Experienced leadership under Clutterbuck (in command since 1941)
known_issues: No desert warfare experience (unlike 8th Army divisions)
Arrived late Q1 - limited time for acclimatization before May offensive
First experience of North African terrain and climate
Learning curve for combined operations in hilly terrain
Need to integrate with First Army tactical procedures
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Not a desert division - operating in northern Tunisia's hilly, fertile terrain. Adaptations needed: Mediterranean climate adjustment, hill fighting tactics, coordination with armor in restrictive terrain.

historical_context.operational_status: Active - Arrived Tunisia 9 March 1943, preparing for final offensive
major_battles: Q1 1943: NO MAJOR BATTLES - Division arrived 9 March, spent remainder of Q1 (22 days) in training/acclimatization
Medjez-Bou Arada sector occupation (March 1943) - quiet sector for preparation
Banana Ridge defense (21 April 1943) - 3rd Brigade, outside Q1 timeframe
Operation Vulcan (6-13 May 1943) - final Tunisia offensive, outside Q1 timeframe
notes: Division departed UK 28 February 1943, arrived North Africa 9 March 1943
Moved to Medjez-Bou Arada area for acclimatization
Q1 1943: ONLY 22 DAYS IN THEATER (9-31 March)
Part of V Corps, British First Army under Lieutenant-General Kenneth Anderson
Walter Clutterbuck commanded since 1941, retained command through Tunisia and Italy
Division fresh from UK with full establishment and modern equipment
24th Guards Brigade initially assigned, later replaced by 18th Infantry Brigade
Supported by 142nd Regiment RAC (Churchill tanks) - not organic
April-May 1943 operations: Banana Ridge (21 Apr), Operation Vulcan (6-13 May)

scenario_suitability: British First Army vs. Afrika Korps/Italian forces
Hill fighting in Northern Tunisia terrain
special_rules: Fresh from UK - no desert experience penalty but no desert experience bonus
Full equipment allocation (no shortages like 8th Army divisions)
Combined arms training with Churchill tanks (142nd RAC)
Learning curve modifier for first operations in theater
historical_engagements: Q1 1943: Training and acclimatization only (arrived 9 March)
Banana Ridge defense (21 April 1943 - outside Q1)
Operation Vulcan final offensive (6-13 May 1943 - outside Q1)

source: WebSearch: Walter Clutterbuck commander British 1st Infantry Division

brigade_commanders.reason: Brigade commander names for 2nd, 3rd, and 24th Guards Brigades not documented in available sources for March 1943 period
sources_checked: Wikipedia First Army order of battle 20 April 1943
WebSearch for specific brigade commanders - no results
brigade_commanders.mitigation: Brigade organization and composition documented. Commander names would require consultation of War Diaries or regimental histories from UK National Archives.

known_gaps: Exact battalion compositions within brigades (approximated from standard structure)
Precise vehicle allocations by unit (estimated from divisional establishment)
Q1 1943 combat activity limited (division only in theater 22 days)
notes: CRITICAL CONTEXT: Division only in North Africa for 22 days of Q1 1943 (arrived 9 March)
No significant Q1 combat operations - acclimatization and training period only
Major combat operations occurred in Q2 1943 (April-May: Banana Ridge, Operation Vulcan)
Equipment and personnel based on standard 1943 British infantry division establishment
Unit-specific information: Commander (Clutterbuck), brigades (2nd, 3rd, 24th Guards), parent formation (V Corps, First Army)
Tier 2 classification due to: limited Q1 operational data, brigade commander gaps, reliance on standard establishments
Higher confidence for Q2 1943 extraction would be possible (full operational record)
Supply/logistics excellent (fresh from UK, full First Army support)
Division represents British First Army characteristics vs. 8th Army divisions
